awd_titl_txt: Computer Science and Computational Thinking in Early Elementary Classes
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on integrating computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) in second and third grade content classrooms, using effective research-based strategies. As the world’s economy is becoming more dependent on computers and networks, the United States is seeing a critical shortage of CS/CT workers. This shortage could be offset if the CS/CT workforce was proportionally represented by women and underserved minorities. Currently, women make up only 26% of the CS workforce and underserved minorities make up only 8%. The project will target second and third grade teachers who will create CS/CT curriculum content units for their students. Girls and underserved minorities will be a specific focus. The project will integrate CS/CT curriculum units into all second and third grade academic classes in two elementary schools. The project will provide professional development (PD) to the teachers on effective research-based strategies that have been proven to motivate and interest girls and underserved minorities in CS/CT. During the PD, the teachers will apply what they have learned to create model content curriculum units for their classrooms. They will subsequently teach the units to their students. Researchers and school district personnel will work together to maximize the practical implementation of the project so that it can be successfully scaled to other grades and districts. 

This project is a Design-Based Implementation Research (DBIR) project where participating teachers will develop and deploy several prototype content-based CS/CT curriculum units. Through the creation and implementation of these units, the teachers will increase their confidence and effectiveness in applying CS/CT in their content classrooms (language arts, social studies, and math). The teacher’s confidence in creating CS/CT content will be measured using pre/post self-efficacy surveys during the PD, and the teaching of the CS/CT curriculum units. They will reflect and share their experiences with each other through a Professional Learning Community (PLC). The PLC will help the teachers learn together which strategies are most effective for teaching CS/CT to their students. Additionally, a district-level Advisory Board will monitor the progress of the teachers and identify ways that the district can remove any obstacles to success. The ultimate purpose of this project is to help empower the district to continually increase the number of students who are interested in pursuing advanced CS classes and careers in CS. This project is funded by the CS for All program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of our project was to implement Computer Science and Computational Thinking (CS/CT) in elementary classrooms. We partnered with a school district with a stable and experienced teacher population. We organized a Research Practitioner Partnership (RPP) with the district that included educational researchers from two universities, district administrators and district school board members. We thought this group would be able to help us navigate any administrative roadblocks that the project might face and provide us with valuable insight into what interventions are possible in the classroom and district. We set up a professional learning community (PLC) with the teachers in our project. This served many objectives. It built community among the teachers, provided the teachers with peer support throughout the project, and provided the researchers with the teacher’s intuitive insights during the project. Our goal was to provide professional development (PD) for the teachers on CS/CT during the summer during which time they would create lesson plans to integrate CS/CT into their classroom instruction. During the three years we hoped that the teachers would become more skilled and comfortable integrating CS/CT into their lessons.

Our grant was funded in 2020 just after the pandemic hit. This created many unexpected alterations to our project. On the positive side, like other school districts around the country, our partner school district was forced to invest heavily in technology for virtual classrooms. Students were given tablets to use at home to connect to their classrooms, and Internet access was expanded drastically. This played into our project nicely, but completely threw the teacher’s world into chaos.

We studied two underserved elementary schools in the district. The teachers were all the 2nd grade and 6th grade teachers at the schools. We wanted to contrast younger elementary student to older elementary students with regards to their responses to CS/CT.

Outcomes and Findings

RPP (Research Partnership Program):
The RPP proved to be highly effective. District Administrators played a vital role in identifying teacher workdays, storing, and distributing Computer Science (CS) and Computational Thinking (CT) materials, especially through the district’s secured network. Their insights into the feasibility of our plans were invaluable. Additionally, board members contributed by fostering community support and gathering parent feedback. We quickly recognized the importance of involving principals in the RPP, which we initially overlooked. Their involvement was crucial for facilitating release time, addressing school-site issues, and managing logistics. Teachers often approached their principals with concerns they were hesitant to share with researchers, revealing critical insights about feeling overwhelmed by pandemic-related challenges while participating in the project.

Teacher Professional Development (PD):
We initially assumed that teachers would feel comfortable developing their curricula, given their responsibility for classroom content. However, we learned that they preferred pre-designed curricula, which they could adapt and provide feedback on after implementation. Financial incentives for creating curriculum or attending summer PD were not sufficient motivators.

Teacher Professional Learning Communities (PLC):
The PLC proved effective throughout the project. Monthly meetings allowed researchers to either prepare teachers for upcoming lesson plans or review their feedback post-implementation. Teachers appreciated the opportunity to share their experiences and felt heard by researchers, resulting in the development of many effective lesson plans. Interestingly, in the second and third years, teachers expressed a desire to collaborate on creating CS/CT-integrated units at each school site. They not only incorporated CS/CT into their lessons but also integrated various subject areas into thematic units, such as one focused on the Iditarod in Alaska. Despite their enthusiasm, teachers believed that lesson planning should primarily rest with curriculum coaches or specialists. Moving forward, we anticipate that utilizing volunteer teachers will prove more effective.

Student Outcomes:
All students exhibited increased motivation due to the focus on CS/CT activities. Second graders particularly thrived in physical computing, where they could see immediate results from their coding efforts. Teachers noted that Code and Go Mouse robots were a student favorite, along with Scratch Jr., albeit to a lesser extent. Various methods emerged for integrating these tools into lessons. In contrast, sixth graders engaged with CS/CT in more advanced applications, such as creating graphic stories with Pixton, a powerful tool for enhancing writing, equity, and inclusion. They also discovered innovative ways to incorporate databases and spreadsheets across their curriculum, utilizing them for tasks like packing lists, polls, budgets, and recording experimental results.

Future Directions:
The project is entering a new phase, with plans to expand the initial initiative to the remaining 31 elementary schools in the district. Additionally, the district intends to establish a CS/CT pipeline that spans from elementary education through high school graduation.
